unnormalised: Okay, here's the generated text based on your specifications:
normalised: Okay, so you are heading to the sabzi mandi, huh? Or maybe D-Mart, or even just Sharmaji's Kirana store down the street. Does not matter where, buying veggies and groceries often involves a little mental math with all those units flying around! Do not worry, we have all been there.

unnormalised: Okay, so you're heading to the sabzi mandi, huh? Or maybe DMart, or even just Sharmaji's Kirana store down the street. Doesn't matter where, buying veggies and groceries often involves a little mental math with all those units flying around! Don't worry, we've all been there.
normalised: First up, potatoes. Usually sold by the kilogram, right? But sometimes the vendor's weighing scale is a bit wonky, and he might say "Ek kilo mein eight hundred grams hai, chalega?" (There are eight hundred grams in one kilo, is that okay?). Knowing that one kilogram is equal to one thousand grams helps you quickly decide if you are getting a fair deal. Remember that conversion.

unnormalised: First up, potatoes. Usually sold by the kilogram, right? But sometimes the vendor's weighing scale is a bit wonky, and he might say "Ek kilo mein 800 grams hai, chalega?" (There are 800 grams in one kilo, is that okay?). Knowing that 1 kg is equal to 1000 g helps you quickly decide if you're getting a fair deal. Remember that conversion.
normalised: Then there is spinach. Palak. So green, so healthy. Usually sold by the bunch. But what if you are making saag paneer and the recipe calls for "two hundred and fifty grams of spinach"? Time to estimate! Most small bunches are probably around two hundred to three hundred grams, so grab one and a half, roughly. Or ask Sharmaji to weigh it for you. No shame in that game!

unnormalised: Then there's spinach. Palak. So green, so healthy. Usually sold by the bunch. But what if you're making saag paneer and the recipe calls for "250 grams of spinach"? Time to estimate! Most small bunches are probably around 200-300 g, so grab one and a half, roughly. Or ask Sharmaji to weigh it for you. No shame in that game!
normalised: And what about the atta? (flour) You will usually buy this in bags of five kilogram or ten kilogram. I always think five kilogram atta bag goes a long way, but it is surprising how fast that gets over. Then you are back at the shop within a month for atta again.

unnormalised: And what about the atta? (flour) You'll usually buy this in bags of 5 kg or 10 kg. I always think 5Kg atta bag goes a long way, but it is surprising how fast that gets over. Then you are back at the shop within a month for atta again.
normalised: Next, consider tomatoes. Nowadays, they are being sold at about rupee one hundred per kilogram in Bengaluru. But sometimes, you only need a few for your curry. The shopkeeper says two hundred and fifty grams for rupee twenty five. This is when you need to calculate cost per kilogram.

unnormalised: Next, consider tomatoes. Nowadays, they are being sold at about ₹100/kg in Bengaluru. But sometimes, you only need a few for your curry. The shopkeeper says 250g for ₹25. This is when you need to calculate cost per kilogram.
normalised: Now let us talk about oil. It is usually sold by the liter. But sometimes you find it in milliliter (milliliters) too. And remember, one liter equals one thousand milliliter. My mom always buys five liter cans of sunflower oil, whereas my cousin usually buys one liter to avoid storing too much.

unnormalised: Now let’s talk about oil. It's usually sold by the litre. But sometimes you find it in ml (millilitres) too. And remember, 1 litre equals 1000 ml. My mom always buys 5L cans of sunflower oil, whereas my cousin usually buys 1L to avoid storing too much.
normalised: Lastly, keep an eye out for those pesky "per piece" items. Bananas? Maybe rupees five per piece. But are they tiny little ones or those big, fancy Cavendish bananas? This is one area where you are better off estimating by weight because, in some supermarkets, you can get a kilo of bananas for just forty rupees. So be mindful.

unnormalised: Lastly, keep an eye out for those pesky "per piece" items. Bananas? Maybe Rs. 5 per piece. But are they tiny little ones or those big, fancy Cavendish bananas? This is one area where you are better off estimating by weight because, in some supermarkets, you can get a kilo of bananas for just 40 rupees. So be mindful.
normalised: So, next time you are stocking up on groceries, remember these little unit conversions and tricks. Happy shopping!

unnormalised: So, next time you're stocking up on groceries, remember these little unit conversions and tricks. Happy shopping!
